content.raw:
I agree with Louise here and really like your proposal more than have a strict limit. Increase testing rate motivated only to increase testing rate is not a good business, I think. Even giving that we are mixing here coverage of unit, integration and system. [Some nice graphs](http://www.bullseye.com/coverage.html#intermediate) to think about the testing productivity.

I think that your current proposal is fine, let's give it a try and see how the team works with this.
content.html:
I agree with Louise here and really like your proposal more than have a strict limit. Increase testing rate motivated only to increase testing rate is not a good business, I think. Even giving that we are mixing here coverage of unit, integration and system. Some nice graphs to think about the testing productivity.

I think that your current proposal is fine, let's give it a try and see how the team works with this.

content.raw:
Just my 2 cents about branch coverage. I think at some level, requiring high branch coverage might discourage people to add simple checks, such as checks for null pointers, as these might be difficult to reproduce in tests but are important during race conditions for example.

Or maybe what I just said doesn't make sense...
content.html:
Just my 2 cents about branch coverage. I think at some level, requiring high branch coverage might discourage people to add simple checks, such as checks for null pointers, as these might be difficult to reproduce in tests but are important during race conditions for example.

Or maybe what I just said doesn't make sense...

pull_request.title: Added documentation for test coverage, and a section for internal developers.

pullrequest.title: Added documentation for test coverage, and a section for internal developers.

content.raw:
We should shoot for 100% coverage, for both line and branch. In many cases the limiting case of reaching that mark is the time needed to write tests. There are cases where it's extremely difficult or impossible to fully test every line and branch, and in some cases the coverage tool reports incorrect information. 

Specifying a coverage number is useful for creating a minimal barrier. Our actual development effort should be focused on reaching 100% coverage. For example, it would be bad for a developer to write tests that just get past the minimum limits and then stop. I'd rather hear "I tried to get to 100%, but here are the problems that prevented me." instead of "My pull request just meets the coverage requirements".

How about I rephrase these sentences to be:

"A pull request will only be accepted if it has tests. The goal is to achieve 100% line and branch coverage. However, this is not always possible due to complexity issues, analysis tools misreporting coverage, and in some cases time constraints. A more realistic goal is 90% line and 75% branch coverage. However, do not let those coverage numbers stop you from writing more complete tests."
content.html:
We should shoot for 100% coverage, for both line and branch. In many cases the limiting case of reaching that mark is the time needed to write tests. There are cases where it's extremely difficult or impossible to fully test every line and branch, and in some cases the coverage tool reports incorrect information.

Specifying a coverage number is useful for creating a minimal barrier. Our actual development effort should be focused on reaching 100% coverage. For example, it would be bad for a developer to write tests that just get past the minimum limits and then stop. I'd rather hear "I tried to get to 100%, but here are the problems that prevented me." instead of "My pull request just meets the coverage requirements".

How about I rephrase these sentences to be:

"A pull request will only be accepted if it has tests. The goal is to achieve 100% line and branch coverage. However, this is not always possible due to complexity issues, analysis tools misreporting coverage, and in some cases time constraints. A more realistic goal is 90% line and 75% branch coverage. However, do not let those coverage numbers stop you from writing more complete tests."

pull_request.title: Added documentation for test coverage, and a section for internal developers.

pullrequest.title: Added documentation for test coverage, and a section for internal developers.

content.raw:
Sorry, mu fault for not including a reference in the comment before, but a quick note on the coverage rate: 90% of function is pretty high, but a nice goal for software projects. Not difficult to achieve but it will require time. We could go with it, although we can decrease it a bit so we don't stop our development speed, or review the numbers after a month of testing. I'm not in favor of having a 90% in condition/decision coverage, is probably too much and not easy to get. The avionic industry only requires 100% of it when someone can be injured but even having a bug that ends in a change in the flight plan is ok not to have that rate. I would be more than happy if we can reach a 50%.

[This document](http://www.bullseye.com/minimum.html) about minimun coverage from the own bullseye team provides some guidance.
content.html:
Sorry, mu fault for not including a reference in the comment before, but a quick note on the coverage rate: 90% of function is pretty high, but a nice goal for software projects. Not difficult to achieve but it will require time. We could go with it, although we can decrease it a bit so we don't stop our development speed, or review the numbers after a month of testing. I'm not in favor of having a 90% in condition/decision coverage, is probably too much and not easy to get. The avionic industry only requires 100% of it when someone can be injured but even having a bug that ends in a change in the flight plan is ok not to have that rate. I would be more than happy if we can reach a 50%.

This document about minimun coverage from the own bullseye team provides some guidance.

content.raw: As you mention, it goes both ways. A class function should be `CamelCase`, but member variables should be `camelCase`.

content.raw: The code check we use is [cpplint.py](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/default/tools/cpplint.py?at=default) from google. It is useful to tell people where we got our style from (we didn't pick out style completely out of thin air), even if we have some changes.
content.html: The code check we use is cpplint.py from google. It is useful to tell people where we got our style from (we didn't pick out style completely out of thin air), even if we have some changes.

content.raw: I'm not sure if it's very helpful to point new collaborators to the google style guide because it is quite long and there are divergences with our style. Just starting to read it I see they use `.h` for headers instead of `.hh`, for example. Variable names are also different, they explicitly say `thisIsBad`.
content.html: I'm not sure if it's very helpful to point new collaborators to the google style guide because it is quite long and there are divergences with our style. Just starting to read it I see they use .h for headers instead of .hh, for example. Variable names are also different, they explicitly say thisIsBad.
